laws.summary: South Dakota does not have a statewide law prohibiting employers from asking applicants about salary history.
requirements: Employers may legally ask about prior salary
Use of salary history may increase discrimination risk under federal law
Best practice is to avoid salary history inquiries
laws.notes: Although legal, many employers avoid salary history questions to reduce Title VII and Equal Pay Act risk.

laws.summary: South Dakota does not require employers to disclose wage ranges in job postings or offer letters.
laws.statute_citation: No current statute mandating pay transparency
requirements: Wage range disclosure is not legally required
Employers may voluntarily disclose compensation information
Federal equal pay and anti-discrimination laws still apply
laws.notes: Multi-state employers may still disclose pay ranges to comply with other state laws.

laws.summary: Non-compete agreements are generally enforceable in South Dakota if reasonable in duration, geography, and scope and if they protect legitimate business interests.
requirements: Must protect legitimate business interests
Must be reasonable in duration
Must be reasonable in geographic scope
Cannot impose undue hardship on the employee
Overly broad restrictive covenants may be invalidated by courts
laws.notes: South Dakota courts generally apply reasonableness standards similar to many employer-friendly states.

laws.summary: South Dakota does not have a statewide ban-the-box law for private employers, but federal FCRA requirements apply when using background check vendors.
laws.statute_citation: Fair Credit Reporting Act (15 U.S.C. ยง 1681)
requirements: Written consent required before third-party background checks
Must provide pre-adverse action notice before taking negative action
Must provide copy of report and summary of rights
Must issue adverse action notice if decision is finalized
Criminal history use must be non-discriminatory
laws.notes: Applies whenever a consumer reporting agency is used.

laws.summary: South Dakota does not mandate paid sick leave statewide but protects certain civic leave rights.
laws.statute_citation: S.D. Codified Laws ยง 16-13-10.6 (jury duty); ยง 12-3-5 (voting leave)
requirements: Employees must be allowed leave for jury duty
Employers cannot penalize employees for jury service
Employees must be allowed time off to vote if work schedule conflicts with polling hours
No statewide paid sick leave requirement
laws.notes: Offer letters should not conflict with statutory civic leave protections.

laws.summary: South Dakota permits workplace drug testing. Recreational cannabis use is illegal and not protected in employment.
laws.statute_citation: South Dakota Codified Laws Title 60; criminal law provisions on marijuana
requirements: Employers may maintain drug-free workplace policies
Drug testing policies should be applied consistently
Employers may discipline or refuse hire based on positive marijuana tests
Employers may prohibit impairment during work
laws.notes: South Dakota is employer-friendly regarding drug testing and cannabis-related policies.

laws.summary: Arbitration agreements are generally enforceable in South Dakota if consistent with contract law and federal arbitration principles.
laws.statute_citation: Federal Arbitration Act; South Dakota contract law
requirements: Agreement must be clear and voluntary
Must not be unconscionable
Must provide reasonable notice
Courts may invalidate one-sided clauses

laws.summary: South Dakota follows the at-will employment doctrine, subject to contractual, statutory, and public policy exceptions.
requirements: Employment is presumed at-will unless contract provides otherwise
Cannot terminate for discriminatory reasons
Cannot retaliate for protected activity
Public policy exceptions apply
Employee handbooks may create implied obligations
laws.notes: Clear at-will language in offer letters is recommended.

laws.summary: South Dakota law prohibits discrimination in employment based on protected characteristics and largely mirrors federal civil rights protections.
laws.statute_citation: South Dakota Human Relations Act (S.D. Codified Laws ยง 20-13-1 et seq.)
requirements: Cannot discriminate based on race, color, religion, sex, national origin
Cannot discriminate based on disability
Cannot discriminate based on age (40+)
Harassment is prohibited
Retaliation for protected activity is prohibited
laws.notes: Offer letters must avoid language implying exclusion or bias.

data_quality.sources: South Dakota Department of Labor and Regulation, South Dakota Codified Laws, South Dakota Division of Human Rights, official state guidance
data_quality.coverage_completeness: comprehensive for offer-letter and hiring compliance

additional_notes.general_guidance: South Dakota is generally employer-friendly, with few statutory hiring restrictions beyond federal law, but strict adherence to anti-discrimination and FCRA requirements is still critical.
enforcement_agencies: South Dakota Department of Labor and Regulation
South Dakota Division of Human Rights

No statewide paid sick leave mandate
Continued reliance on federal FCRA for background check compliance
